iti100:2.1.pli: “Ahamasmi, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇo yācayogo sadā payatapāṇi antimadehadharo anuttaro bhisakko sallakatto.
iti100:2.1.eng: “I, mendicants, am a brahmin, committed to charity, always open-handed, bearing my final body, a healer, a surgeon.

iti100:2.2.pli: Tassa me tumhe puttā orasā mukhato jātā dhammajā dhammanimmitā dhammadāyādā, no āmisadāyādā.
iti100:2.2.eng: You are my true-born sons, born from my mouth, born of the teaching, created by the teaching, heirs in the teaching, not in things of the flesh.

iti100:3.2.eng: A gift of things of the flesh and a gift of the teaching.

iti100:3.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ dānānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammadānaṃ.
iti100:3.3.eng: The better of these two gifts is the gift of the teaching.

iti100:4.1.eng: There are these two kinds of sharing.

iti100:4.2.eng: Sharing things of the flesh and sharing the teaching.

iti100:4.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ saṃvibhāgānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammasaṃvibhāgo.
iti100:4.3.eng: The better of these two kinds of sharing is sharing the teaching.

iti100:5.1.eng: There are these two kinds of support.

iti100:5.2.eng: Support in things of the flesh and support in the teaching.

iti100:5.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ anuggahānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammānuggaho.
iti100:5.3.eng: The better of these two kinds of support is support in the teaching.

iti100:6.2.eng: An offering of things of the flesh and an offering of the teaching.

iti100:6.3.pli: Etadaggaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ dvinnaṃ yāgānaṃ yadidaṃ dhammayāgo”ti.
iti100:6.3.eng: The better of these two offerings is an offering of the teaching.”

iti101:2.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, appāni ceva sulabhāni ca, tāni ca anavajjāni.
iti101:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, these four trifles are easy to find and are blameless.

iti101:2.3.pli: Paṃsukūlaṃ, bhikkhave, cīvarānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.

iti101:2.4.pli: Piṇḍiyālopo, bhikkhave, bhojanānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.

iti101:2.5.pli: Rukkhamūlaṃ, bhikkhave, senāsanānaṃ appañca sulabhañca, tañca anavajjaṃ.
iti101:2.5.eng: Lodgings at the root of a tree …

iti101:2.6.pli: Pūtimuttaṃ, bhikkhave, bhesajjānaṃ appañca sulabhañca tañca anavajjaṃ.

iti101:2.7.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri appāni ceva sulabhāni ca, tāni ca anavajjāni.
iti101:2.7.eng: These four trifles are easy to find and are blameless.

iti101:2.8.pli: Yato kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu appena ca tuṭṭho hoti sulabhena ca anavajjena ca, idamassāhaṃ aññataraṃ sāmaññaṅganti vadāmī”ti.
iti101:2.8.eng: When a mendicant is content with trifles that are easy to find, they have one of the factors of the ascetic life, I say.”

iti102:2.1.pli: “Jānatohaṃ, bhikkhave, passato āsavānaṃ khayaṃ vadāmi, no ajānato no apassato.
iti102:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see.

iti102:2.2.pli: Kiñca, bhikkhave, jānato, kiṃ passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti?
iti102:2.2.eng: For one who knows and sees what?

iti102:2.3.pli: Idaṃ dukkhanti, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti. Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayoti, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhoti, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti. Ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti, bhikkhave, jānato passato āsavānaṃ khayo hoti.
iti102:2.3.eng: The ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

iti102:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, jānato evaṃ passato āsavānaṃ khayo hotī”ti.
iti102:2.4.eng: The ending of the defilements is for one who knows and sees this.”

iti103:2.1.pli: “Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānanti—
iti103:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

iti103:2.2.pli: na me te, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu vā samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu vā brāhmaṇasammatā, na ca panete āyasmanto sāmaññatthaṃ vā brahmaññatthaṃ vā diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti.
iti103:2.2.eng: I don’t deem them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables don’t realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and don’t live having realized it with their own insight.

iti103:3.1.pli: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānanti—
iti103:3.1.eng: There are ascetics and brahmins who truly understand about suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.

iti103:3.2.pli: te kho me, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā samaṇesu ceva samaṇasammatā brāhmaṇesu ca brāhmaṇasammatā, te ca panāyasmanto sāmaññatthañca brahmaññatthañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharantī”ti.
iti103:3.2.eng: I regard them as true ascetics and brahmins. Those venerables realize the goal of life as an ascetic or brahmin, and live having realized it with their own insight.”

iti104:2.1.pli: “Ye te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sīlasampannā samādhisampannā paññāsampannā vimuttisampannā vimuttiñāṇadassanasampannā ovādakā viññāpakā sandassakā samādapakā samuttejakā sampahaṃsakā alaṃsamakkhātāro saddhammassa dassanampahaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahūpakāraṃ vadāmi;
iti104:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, take a mendicant who is accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom. They advise and instruct. They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire, and can rightly explain the true teaching. Even the sight of those mendicants is very helpful, I say.

iti104:2.2.pli: savanampahaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahūpakāraṃ vadāmi;

iti104:2.3.pli: upasaṅkamanampahaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahūpakāraṃ vadāmi;

iti104:2.4.pli: payirupāsanampahaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahūpakāraṃ vadāmi;

iti104:2.5.pli: anussaraṇampahaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahūpakāraṃ vadāmi;

iti104:2.6.pli: anupabbajjampahaṃ, bhikkhave, tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ bahūpakāraṃ vadāmi.
iti104:2.6.eng: or go forth after them is very helpful, I say.

iti104:2.8.pli: Tathārūpe, bhikkhave, bhikkhū sevato bhajato payirupāsato aparipūropi sīlakkhandho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati, aparipūropi samādhikkhandho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati, aparipūropi paññākkhandho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati, aparipūropi vimuttikkhandho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati, aparipūropi vimuttiñāṇadassanakkhandho bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchati.
iti104:2.8.eng: For one who frequents and associates with such mendicants, their incomplete spectrum of ethics is completed. Their incomplete spectrum of immersion … wisdom … freedom … knowledge and vision of freedom is completed.

iti104:2.9.pli: Evarūpā ca te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū satthārotipi vuccanti, satthavāhātipi vuccanti, raṇañjahātipi vuccanti, tamonudātipi vuccanti, ālokakarātipi vuccanti, obhāsakarātipi vuccanti, pajjotakarātipi vuccanti, ukkādhārātipi vuccanti, pabhaṅkarātipi vuccanti, ariyātipi vuccanti, cakkhumantotipi vuccantī”ti.
iti104:2.9.eng: Such mendicants are called ‘teachers’, ‘caravan leaders’, ‘strife-discarders’, ‘dispellers of darkness’, ‘bringers of light’, ‘luminaries’, ‘lamps’, ‘candlebearers’, ‘beacons’, ‘noble ones’, and ‘clear-eyed ones’.”

iti105:2.1.pli: “Cattārome, bhikkhave, taṇhuppādā, yattha bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.
iti105:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four things that give rise to craving in a mendicant.

iti105:2.3.pli: Cīvarahetu vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati;

iti105:2.4.pli: piṇḍapātahetu vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati;

iti105:2.5.pli: senāsanahetu vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati;

iti105:2.6.pli: itibhavābhavahetu vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati.
iti105:2.6.eng: or rebirth in this or that state.

iti105:2.7.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cattāro taṇhuppādā yattha bhikkhuno taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjatī”ti.
iti105:2.7.eng: These are the four things that give rise to craving in a mendicant.”

iti106:2.1.pli: “Sabrahmakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
iti106:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, a family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with Divinity.

iti106:2.2.pli: Sapubbadevatāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
iti106:2.2.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with the elder gods.

iti106:2.3.pli: Sapubbācariyakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
iti106:2.3.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with the first tutors.

iti106:2.4.pli: Sāhuneyyakāni, bhikkhave, tāni kulāni yesaṃ puttānaṃ mātāpitaro ajjhāgāre pūjitā honti.
iti106:2.4.eng: A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with those worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods.

iti106:3.1.eng: ‘Divinity’ is a term for your parents.

iti106:3.2.eng: ‘Elder gods’ is a term for your parents.

iti106:3.3.eng: ‘First tutors’ is a term for your parents.

iti106:3.4.eng: ‘Worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods’ is a term for your parents.

iti106:3.6.pli: Bahukārā, bhikkhave, mātāpitaro puttānaṃ āpādakā posakā imassa lokassa dassetāro”ti.
iti106:3.6.eng: Parents are very helpful to their children, they raise them, nurture them, and show them the world.”

iti106:6.3.eng: they’re praised in this life by the astute,

iti106:6.4.eng: and they depart to rejoice in heaven.”

iti107:2.1.pli: “Bahukārā, bhikkhave, brāhmaṇagahapatikā tumhākaṃ ye vo paccupaṭṭhitā cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānapaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi.
iti107:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, brahmins and householders are very helpful to you, as they provide you with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.

iti107:2.2.pli: Tumhepi, bhikkhave, bahukārā brāhmaṇagahapatikānaṃ yaṃ nesaṃ dhammaṃ desetha ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāsetha.
iti107:2.2.eng: And you are very helpful to brahmins and householders, as you teach them the Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And you reveal a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

iti107:2.3.pli: Evamidaṃ, bhikkhave, aññamaññaṃ nissāya brahmacariyaṃ vussati oghassa nittharaṇatthāya sammā dukkhassa antakiriyāyā”ti.
iti107:2.3.eng: That is how this spiritual path is lived supporting each other in order to cross over the flood and make a complete end of suffering.”

iti108:2.1.pli: “Ye keci, bhikkhave, bhikkhū kuhā thaddhā lapā siṅgī unnaḷā asamāhitā, na me te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū māmakā.
iti108:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, those mendicants who are deceivers and flatterers, pompous and fake, insolent and scattered: those mendicants are no followers of mine.

iti108:2.2.pli: Apagatā ca te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmā dhammavinayā; na ca te imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjanti.
iti108:2.2.eng: They’ve left this teaching and training, and they don’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.

iti108:2.3.pli: Ye ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhū nikkuhā nillapā dhīrā atthaddhā susamāhitā, te kho me, bhikkhave, bhikkhū māmakā.
iti108:2.3.eng: But those mendicants who are genuine, not flatterers, attentive, amenable, and serene: those mendicants are followers of mine.

iti108:2.4.pli: Anapagatā ca te, bhikkhave, bhikkhū imasmā dhammavinayā; te ca imasmiṃ dhammavinaye vuddhiṃ virūḷhiṃ vepullaṃ āpajjantī”ti.
iti108:2.4.eng: They haven’t left this teaching and training, and they do achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.”

iti108:3.3.eng: these don’t grow in the teaching

iti108:3.4.eng: that was taught by the perfected Buddha.

iti108:4.1.eng: But those who are genuine, not flatterers, attentive,

iti108:4.3.eng: these do grow in the teaching

iti108:4.4.eng: that was taught by the perfected Buddha.”
